intro: Corchorus hirtus var. glabellus, commonly known as the woolly knotweed, is a flowering plant native to parts of Asia and the Middle East. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus. The plant is characterized by its hairy stems and heart-shaped leaves, which are often covered in fine, soft hairs. Its flowers are small, clustered in spikes, and typically have five petals. It is often found in wet or marshy habitats, where it thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils.
